questions.question: The earliest evidence of self-medication in prehistoric humans comes from fossilized dental calculus of Neanderthals found in which location?

This site contains evidence of surgical amputation (31,000 years ago), not dental calculus analysis
Gas-chromatography mass spectrometry analysis of Neanderthal dental calculus from El Sidrón cave (50,000 years ago) revealed microfossils of medicinal plants like yarrow and chamomile
Ötztal Alps is where Ötzi the Iceman was found (5,300 years ago), not Neanderthal dental evidence

questions.explanation: Key distinction: El Sidrón cave provided the earliest direct chemical evidence of medicinal plant consumption through dental calculus analysis. Mehrgarh relates to dentistry/drilling, Liang Tebo to amputation, and Ötztal to the Iceman mummy.

Clay/soil were consumed through geophagy for mineral supplementation and toxin neutralization, but not identified as plant microfossils in dental calculus

questions.explanation: Critical detail: Yarrow and chamomile were chemically identified in 50,000-year-old Neanderthal dental calculus. Willow bark (pain relief) and catnip (stomach problems) were used later but not in this specific Neanderthal population.

questions.question: Trepanning (cranial drilling) has been practiced since approximately when?

questions.explanation: Common confusion: Trepanning (10,000 BCE) is distinct from other prehistoric medical practices. Surgical amputation evidence dates to 31,000 BCE (Borneo) and 7,000 BCE (France); dentistry to 9,000 BCE (Mehrgarh). Trepanning remains part of modern neurosurgery for intracranial pressure relief.

This corresponds to surgical amputation evidence in Borneo

questions.explanation: Distinction: Mehrgarh (9,000 years ago, Indus Valley) shows the earliest evidence of intentional dental drilling. This predates written records by millennia and demonstrates sophisticated understanding of dental pain management.

questions.explanation: Important update: While the Neolithic French site (7,000 years ago) was long considered the earliest amputation evidence, the 2022 Nature study of Liang Tebo cave pushed this back to 31,000 years ago—demonstrating remarkably advanced surgical knowledge in Paleolithic Southeast Asia.

questions.explanation: Diagnostic evidence: Ötzi's possession of Piptoporus betulinus fungus directly correlates with parasitological findings (whipworm eggs in his intestine), suggesting intentional self-medication. questions.explanation: Historical continuity: Salicin from willow bark is the natural precursor to acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), one of the most widely used modern medications. This demonstrates remarkable continuity between prehistoric empirical knowledge and modern pharmacology.
